unnormalised: Someone asked me about understanding prices and numbers in the Indian retail space, so thought I'd share a few points. It's a mix of tradition and modern practices, and can be a little confusing at first. So, here is what you need to know.
normalised: First thing to understand is the lakh and crore system. Forget millions and billions! In India, large amounts are typically expressed in lakhs (one lakh equals one hundred thousand or one hundred thousand) and crores (one crore equals one crore or ten million). So, you might see something like "This saree costs rupee two lakhs" or "The apartment is priced at rupee two point five crore." Getting comfortable with these units is key. A quick tip, is just to remember that one lakh equals one hundred thousand and one crore equals ten million.

unnormalised: First thing to understand is the Lakh and Crore system. Forget millions and billions! In India, large amounts are typically expressed in lakhs (1 lakh = 1,00,000 or 100,000) and crores (1 crore = 1,00,00,000 or 10,000,000). So, you might see something like "This saree costs Rs. 2 Lakhs" or "The apartment is priced at Rs. 2.5 Crore." Getting comfortable with these units is key. A quick tip, is just to remember that 1 lakh equals 100 thousand and 1 crore equals 10 million.
normalised: Next, be mindful of the abbreviations. "R-s." is the common abbreviation for Rupees, sometimes you will see "rupee symbol" but "R-s." is more common online. Also, prices are often rounded. You might see something sold for rupee nine hundred and ninety nine instead of rupee one thousand, a common psychological pricing tactic. Online, you will also see discounts expressed as percentages, like "twenty percent off" on Flipkart. Do not be surprised to see seemingly random amounts to round up the numbers. For example, the price may be shown as rupee seven hundred and ninety nine plus rupee forty nine (delivery).

normalised: Then, regarding prices including tax, it is important to note whether it is inclusive of all taxes. Usually big stores and online sales will include the total price. The printed price will say something like "M-R-P rupee one thousand two hundred (inclusive of all taxes)". But smaller shops might add tax later. So, it is always a good idea to double-check if the listed price is the final price, especially in smaller establishments or markets like Crawford Market in Mumbai.
